Intro to Java
Well, good choice! Developed in the early 1990's Java has grown to be one of the world's most popular computing languages. So here's what you need to know:

History

Java was first created by James Gosling and his team of researchers at Sun Microsystems inc. They set out with the intent to create a language that enabled electronic devices to communicate with one another. And as you'll learn if you continue to study Java, they succeeded in some major ways. Let's get into the technicality:

Prior to Java, a compiler translated code in programming languages into instructions for a particular type of computer. So Java really changed the game when the Java compiler took java code then turned it into bytecode. Next, bytecode would be interpreted by something called the Java Runtime Environment (JRE) or the Java virtual machine (JVM). The interpreter then translates the code for whatever host computer, no matter the underlying architecture. THIS WAS HUGE.

This meant that in 1995 you in your basement with your parent's desktop computer could call up a friend with a different type of desktop and the two of you could look at the same webpage, same format, same EVERYTHING.

Java is an object oriented programming language. This means that the language was developed around the idea of creating objects. These reusable objects can then be manipulated to perform certain tasks in your program. A simple Java object can look like this: 

import static java.langSystem.out
                            
public class Student {
    String school;
    String name;
    public class Main(String[] args) {
        Student s1 = new Student();
        s1.name = "Joy";
        s1.school = "Wellesley College"
     }
}

You can then add s1 to a list of other student objects or create methods to run in the student class.

Best *IDEs* for this language üéâ

  • BlueJ - There is a reason CS 230 has used this IDE for so many years. This *open-sourced* Java IDE was developed with education in mind thus this simple environment is a great choice for those just starting their journey with Java.
  • IntelliJ Idea - Created by tech giant JetBrains, IntelliJ is a great choice for the programmer that needs a professional Java environment. IntelliJ provides a paid ‚Äúultimate‚Äù experience and a free programming experience. In the free version you'll have support with *git* and *github*, cooperation with *Docker* and more‚Ä¶ (Disclaimer: You will have to pay to develop with languages other than Java.)
  • Apache NetBeans - Free, open source, with built-in tutorials on Java and PHP. Need I say more? Probably. Apache is highly respected for its straightforwardness and its *code refactoring* feature.
  • Android Studio - Everything you need to develop and deploy an Android application using Java.
  • Haven't found quite what you are looking for? Check out the TCS IDE page to explore many more IDEs.

What can you build with this language? üèóÔ∏è

Java is often used to make Android compatible mobile applications. It can also be used to support JavaScript, HTML and CSS in the creation of online web portals.

Geeks for Geeks provides a great list of possible projects if you're looking to boost your Github contributions.

Further resources

If you know the author of this beginner guide, you know she is a big fan of W3Schools. Even after you leave this webpage to inevitably become an expert in Java, you can return to W3schools to brush up on switch cases, java methods, polymorphism and 61 other Java related topics.

Geeks for Geeks offers a thorough introduction to java as well as documentation of Java OOP concepts, flow control, exception handling and much more.

When in doubt, read the Oracle Java documentation. It is not so pleasing on the eyes and may even seem intimidating but if you take it piece by piece it is very helpful. And remember, take what you need, leave what you don't. You are not expected to read documentation front to back, especially because it can change every few years when new versions of Java are released. You can build incredibly impactful projects using Java but those impacts are not always good. Criminal face detection and like-systems have used Java to the detriment of communities of color. If you want to learn more you can turn to one of Alana's favorite documentaries, Coded Bias or the book Race After Technology by the incredible Ruha Benjamin.

Now go forth and create!!

With love,

Alana Mackey
